title: 104_s170
content: The Act may be cited as the "Comprehensive Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Prevention Act". Congress finds that Fetal Alcohol Syndrome is the leading cause of mental retardation, affecting thousands of infants each year in the United States. The issue is particularly alarming among American Indian and Alaska Native communities with high rates of alcohol dependency. Newborns suffering from Fetal Alcohol Syndrome or Fetal Alcohol Effects have costs that are 30 times greater than national averages, leading to significant financial burdens on the nation. Delivery and care costs are four times higher for infants exposed to illicit substances, with estimated lifetime healthcare costs for one child with Fetal Alcohol Syndrome at least $1,400,000. The risks of giving birth to a baby with Fetal Alcohol Syndrome increase with the amount and frequency of alcohol consumed during pregnancy. Stopping alcohol consumption at any point reduces the risks and consequences to the baby. There is no safe dose of alcohol during pregnancy, and the Federal Government should encourage all women to abstain from alcohol during pregnancy. The purpose of this Act is to establish a program within the Department of Health and Human Services to prevent Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Effects nationwide through research, awareness, prevention, and coordination among federal agencies. Establishment of Fetal Alcohol Syndrome Prevention Program under Title III of the Public Health Service Act to prevent Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Effects nationwide through research, awareness, prevention, and coordination among federal agencies. The Secretary shall establish a comprehensive Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects prevention program that includes education, training programs, prevention and education programs for school-age children, and public awareness initiatives. The Secretary shall establish a comprehensive Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects prevention program that includes education, training programs, prevention and education programs for school-age children, public and community awareness programs, technical assistance to various entities, and grants for evaluating program effectiveness. The comprehensive Fetal Alcohol Syndrome prevention program includes training, education for school-age children, and increasing public awareness about the syndrome. The program aims to raise awareness about Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects, conduct research on causes and prevention, and provide assistance to states and tribal governments. The program provides assistance, grants, and training to various organizations for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome prevention, early intervention, research on causes, diagnosis, treatment, and prevention. The program aims to conduct innovative projects for preventing fetal exposure to alcohol, improve surveillance methods for Fetal Alcohol Syndrome, and develop culturally competent prevention programs for children and adolescents. The program includes prevention programs for at-risk individuals, coordination among various levels of government, basic research on prevention treatments for pregnant alcohol-dependent women, and dissemination of information on Fetal Alcohol Syndrome. The establishment of an interagency task force on Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects to coordinate research, programs, and surveillance among Federal agencies and meet the needs of affected populations. The Task Force on Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects, chaired by the Secretary or designee, includes representatives from various relevant federal agencies. Its functions involve coordinating all federal programs and research related to the issue. The Task Force on Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects, chaired by the Secretary or designee, coordinates Federal programs targeting at-risk individuals and providing services to those affected. It collaborates with existing Department of Health and Human Services task forces and reports biennially to the Secretary. The Task Force on Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects, chaired by the Secretary or designee, coordinates Federal programs targeting at-risk individuals and providing services to those affected. It reports biennially to the Secretary and relevant committees of Congress on current and planned activities. The Task Force on Fetal Alcohol Syndrome and Fetal Alcohol Effects, chaired by the Secretary or designee, coordinates Federal programs for at-risk individuals. To be eligible for grants, entities must be State, Indian tribal government, local government, scientific or academic institution, or nonprofit organization. They must submit an application describing intended activities. Appropriations are authorized for fiscal years 1995 through 1998.
